PEOPLE v. NORTH RIVER SUGAR REFINING CO. N. Y. Supreme Court, First District Circuit; January, 1889. 1. Corporations; acts of stockholders constituting corporate acts.] Although a corporation cannot be deprived of its franchises because-of independent and several acts, however illegal, of its stockholders, yet a combination of corporations, by a deed purporting: to be executed by them, requiring all their stockholders to pool their stock in the hands of a board of trustees created for the purpose, who issue trust certificates in lieu of the stock, should vest the-creditors in the various corporations with sufficient stock to qualify them, should receive all the profits of the various corporations, and from the aggregate fund make a uniform dividend to the-holders of the trust certificates, is, if acted on by the corporations, a corporate act, even though not sanctioned by formal vote of the-respective corporations. 2. Trust deed, construction and effect of. J Under such a contract, shareholders cease to occupy the position of cestuis que ti'ustent with regard to the directors of their various corporations; and accept a new and independent relation exclusively with the trust board. 8i Same.] The members of thatboard are not in any just sense genuine-members of the various corporations, for they have no beneficial interest therein, and cannot claim dividends, either in their own right or as trustees for shareholders in any particular corporation, earning a dividend, nor would they be accountable as such for-dividends if declared by the corporations. 4. Same.] The relation between the trustees of the trust and the-directors of the corporation is not the usual relation of shareholders and directors, but a strict contract relation. 5. Corporations; qualifying directors.] Stock in a corporation whose directors are deprived by a “trust deed,” of the discretionary-power to declare dividends, and which is retransferred by the board to a director in the corporation, pursuant to a provision in a “ trust deed,” for the mere purpose of qualifying the director to act as such, and to be retransferred when required, is lifeless stock without beneficial interest, and does not qualify for directorship. 6. Corporations; power to combine.] A voluntary arrangement on the part of a corporation to consolidate its stock with other corporations,. *165Q and. to mass all of the profits of the respective corporations, parties to the arrangement, is an abuse of the powers and privileges conferred by law on the corporation, under the rule—that corporations cannot consolidate their funds or form a partnership, unless authorized by express grant or necessary implication; nor can they enter into any arrangement amounting to a practical consolidation or ‘ copartnership—and is an abuse of the corporate powers and privileges constituting a ground of forfeiture of the corporate franchise. t¡. Forfeiture for acts of members.] It seems that in an action in the nature of quo warranto to dissolve a corporation for abuse or usurpation of power, the court may look beyond the artificial form of the organization and base its judgment of forfeiture of that form upon the acts and omissions of the aggregate members or persons composing the corporation. '8. Contract; restraint of trade.] A combination, the tendency of which is to prevent general competition and to control prices, is detrimental to the public, and consequently unlawful, and a corporation entering into such a combination subjects its franchise to forfeiture. The cases on contracts in restraint of trade collated. D. Definitions; monopoly.] Any combination, the tendency of which is to prevent competition in its broad and general sense and to control, and thus at will, enhance prices to the detriment of the public, is a legal monopoly. 10. Monopoly ; illegality.] While a monopoly in the strict, technical and absolute sense may not be created in an article-—in this case sugar—which can be indefinitely produced, it may, however, be created in a legal sense, whether the supply is restricted by nature or susceptible of indefinite production. Such a monopoly is unlawful and against public policy. 11. Forms.] Form of judgment of forfeiture.* Action to annul a corporation. The attorney-general sued in the name of the People to •declare the franchise of the North Hi ver Sugar Befining Company annulled and forfeited, on the ground that the defendant had brought itself within subdivisions 2 and 5 of section 1798 of the Code of Civil Procedure; which provides: “ Upon leave being granted, as prescribed in *166the next section, the attorney-genera! may bring an action against a corporation created by or under the laws of the-State, to procure a judgment vacating the charter or annulling the existence of the corporation, upon the ground that s it has, either “2. Violated any provision of law, whereby it has forfeited its charter, or become liable to be dissolved by the-abuse of its powers ; or, u 5. Exercised a privilege or franchise not conferred upon it by law.” Roger A. Pryor, for the plaintiff.

Plaintiff’s contention is that by becoming a party to the éombination created by the “ Sugar liefineries Company ” deed, deféndant forfeited its corporate franchises, and incurred judgment of dissolution.

. I. The creation of a corporation is an act of sovereignty {Field on Corporations, § 61) and the consideration of the-grant of corporate franchises is the public benefit (Marshall, Ch. J., in Trustees of Dartmouth College v. Woodward, 4 Wheaton, 518, 637; Binghampton Bridge, 3 Wall. 51, 73 ; 2 Waterman on Corp. § 431).

II. Hence, corporate franchises are granted in trust, and upon condition—in trust on the one hand, that they be exerted- to the attainment of the object for which they are conceded, and, on the other, that they be not abused to the public detriment; upon the condition, that for nonuser or misuser they may be reclaimed by the State in the appropriate judicial proceeding (Sir James Smith’s Case, 4 Modern, 58; City of London v. Vanacker, 1 Lord Raymond, 499 ; People v. Bristol, etc., 23 Wend. 235-6; People v. Fishkill, etc., 27 Barb. 445, 452; Kent, C., in Slee v. Bloom,. 5 Johns. Ch. 380 ; 2 Waterman on Corp. § 427 ; People’v. Bristol, etc., 23 Wend. 236; Ward v. Farwell, 97 Ill. 593; People v. Phoenix Bank, 24 Wend. 433; People v. Dispensary, 7 Lans. 306 ; Ins. Co. v. Needles, 113 U. S. 574 *167Terrett v. Taylor, 9 Cranch, 52; 2 Kent Corn. 312 ; Com. v Bank, 21 Pick. 542 ; A. and A. on Corp. § 774 [9th ed.].

III. Any act of a corporation, in violation of law and to the public detriment, forfeits its franchises (State v. R. R. Company, 45 Wisc. 590; Ches. & Ohio, etc. v. Balt. & Ohio, etc., 4 Gill and Johns. 121; People v. Fishkill etc., 27 Barb. 452).

IV. Acts. and contracts ultra vires of the corporate authority, are illegal, and grounds of forfeiture of the corporate franchises (Taylor on Corp. § 289, 457, 459 ; People v. Utica, 15 Johns. 358; 2 Morawetz on Corp. § 1024; People v. Trustees, 5 Wend. 211; Selden, J., in Bissell v. Mich., &c. R. R., 22 N. Y. 285; Thomas v. City, 12 Wall. 356; Green's Brice,. 708-9 [3d ed.] ; Code Civ. Pro. § 1798, sub. 5; first part Rev. Stats, title III, ch. 18 § 3 ; Laws 1861, ch. 170).

V. The rule that an illegal or unauthorized act is sufficient ground of corporate forfeiture, is abundantly illustrated by adjudicated cases (People v. Bank, Douglass [Mich], 282; People v. Geneva College, 5 Wend. 211; Attorney-General v. R. R. Co., 35 Wisc. 432, 532; State v. Bank, 5 Ohio Stat. 171; Com. v. Bank, 58 Pa. Stat. 383 ; State v. Bank, 33 Miss. 474; State v. R. R. Co., 45 Wisc. 580; People v. Dispensary, 7 Lans. 304; Bank v. State, 1 Blackf. [Ind.], 267; Attorney-General v. R. R. Co., 6 Iredell [Law], 469; People v. Utica Ins. Co., 15 Johns. 358; State v. A. & N. R. R. Co., 4 R. R. & Corporation Journal, 86; Penn. Co. v. St. Louis, etc. R. R. Co., 118 U. S. 290; Kyd on Corp. 479, et seq.; A. and A. on Corp. §§ 774-776; 2 Waterman on Corp. § 427; Green's Brice, 787; People v. Bristol, 23 Wend. 233-250).

VI. A common law ground of forfeiture of corporate franchises, is still available though not embraced within the statute (State v. R. R. Co., 45 Wisc. 589; People v. Bristol, etc., 23 Wend. 222; People v. Palmer, 109 N. Y. 110).

VII. Agreements tending to monopoly, i. e., “any com*168bination among merchants to raise the price of merchandise to the detriment of the public” (Bouvier's Law Dict.), are illegal (Arnot v. Coal Company, 68 N. Y. 559; Stanton v. Allen, 5 Denio, 434; Clancey v. Salt Company, 62 Barb. 395; Hooker v. Vandewater, 4 Denio, 349; People v. Fisher, 14 Wend. 9-19; Coal Co. v. Coal Co., 68 Penn. St. 182; :Salt Co. v. Guthrie, 35 Ohio St. 672; Craft v. McConoughy, 79 Ill. 346; Santa Clara v. Hayes, 38 Alb. L. J. 279; Bank v. King, 44 N. Y. 87; Case of Monopolies, 11 Coke, 84; Raymond v. Leavitt, 46 Mich. 447; India Bag Co. v. Koch, 14 La. Ann. 168 ; Ray v. Mackin, 100 Ill. 246; People v. Stephens, 71 N. Y. 545; Marsh v. Russell, 66 Id. 288; Hartford, etc. v. N. Y., &c. R. R. Co., 3 Robt. 411; Hilton v. Eckersley, 6 Ell. & Bl. 47 ; Central, etc., v. Collins, 40 Ga. 646). And in all the cases adjudging monopoly agreements and combinations to be illegal, the ground of decision is, that they tend to the public prejudice, by preventing competition and enhancing prices (Charles River Bridge v. Warren Bridge, 11 Peters, 567; 2 Kent, 271, marginal note c; India Bag Co. v. Koch, 14 La. Ann. 168; Stewart v. Company, 17 Minn. 372; Gas Co. v. Gas Co., 2 Am. State Reports ; City v. Gas Light Co., 70 Mo. 69 ; Salt Co. v. Guthrie, 35 Ohio St. 666; The Case of Monopolies, 11 Coke, 84; Santa Clara, etc. v. Hayes, 38 Albany L. J. 276; Arnot v. Coal Company, 68 N. Y. 558; People v. Fisher, 14 Wend. 9, 19 ; West Virginia, etc. v. Ohio, etc. Company, 46 Am. Rep. 527 ; Stanton v. Allen, 5 Denio, 434, 441; Hooker v. Vandewater, 4 Id. 349, 353; Craft v. McConoughy, 79 Ill. 346, 350; People v. Stephens, 71 N. Y. 545; Marsh v. Russell, 66 Id. 292 ; Hartford, etc. R. R. Co. v. N. Y. & N. H. R. R. Co., 3 Robt. 415 ; Brisbane v. Adams, 3 N. Y. 129; Livermore v. Bushnell, 5 Hun, 285; Wright v. Rider, 36 Cal. 342; Western Union v. R. R. Company, 11 Fed. Rep. 3; Western Union v. Company, 23 Id. 12; Balt., etc., Co. v. Company, 24 Id. 319 ; Western Union v. Company, 65 Ga. 160; Denver v. Company, 15 Fed. Rep. *169650, Crawford v. Wick, 18 Ohio St. 190; Parker, J., in Mitchel v. Reynolds, 1 P. Williams, 181; Dunlop v. Gregory, 10 N. Y. 244; Lawrence v. Kidder, 10 Barb. 642; Chappel v. Brockway, 21 Wend. 163; Leslie v. Lorillard, 110 N. Y. 519).

VIII. The combination created by “ The Sugar Refineries Company ” deed, being injurious to trade and commerce, is a criminal conspiracy, and an indictable offense. It was so at common law (Raymond v. Leavitt, 46 Mich. 447; Rex v. De Berenger, 3 M. and S. 67; Rex v. Hilbers, 2 Chitty, 163 ; Rex v. Waddington, 1 East, 143, 167 ; Rex v. Sterling, 1 Keble, 650; Anonymous, 12 Modern, 248; People v. Melvin, 2 Wheeler's Cr. Cas. 262; Com. v. Carlisle, Brightley [Pa.], 36; 4 Black. Com. 158-9; 1 Bish. Cr. Law, § 969; 1 Russ. Cr. Law, 1688; 3 Inst. c. 891). It is so in the State of Hew York by express provision of statute (Penal Code, § 168, subd. 6; People v. Fisher, 14 Wend. 9 ; Morris Run Co. v. Barclay, 68 Pa. St. 174; Hooker v. Vandewater, 4 Denio, 349; Clancey v. Salt Co., 62 Barb. 395).

IX. The character of the combination, whether tending •to monopoly and injurious to the public, will be determined by the provisions of the instrument constituting it, and with•ont reference to its effects in actual operation (Salt Co. v. Guthrie, 35 Ohio St. 678; Hilton v. Eckersley, 6 Ellis & Bl. 47, 65; Clancey v. Salt Company, 62 Barb. 406; Folger, J., in Atcheson v. Mallon, 43 N. Y. 149). hi or will •the court be deceived by the plausible professions of purpose •on the face of the paper, but will construe it upon its manifest tendency (Hooker v. Vandewater, 4 Denio, 352; Stanton v. Allen, 5 Id. 440 ; Matter of Jacobs, 98 N. Y. 110 ; Mugler v. Kansas, 123 U. S. 661).

X. “ The Sugar Refineries Company ” deed constitutes a •combination tending to monopoly, the prevention of competition, and the enhancement of prices (1 Mill’s Principles of Political Economy, 556 ; 2 Id. 378; Wealth of Nations, *17064; 1 Mill, 546, 552, 558, 560). The agreement constitutes a strict and absolute monopoly. Its object is to concentrate the control of the production of refined sugar under the dominion- of a single will, and that will stimulated by self-interest to push the price of the commodity to the highest possible point (Penn. R. R. Co. v. Com., 7 Atlantic R. 3.68). It is entirely obvious that this scheme of combination? bears no similitude or analogy to the aggregations of capital to which, for purposes of apology, ,it is attempted to liken it,, namely, to such concentrations of capital and business as-are exhibited by Macy, Wanamaker and others of the same-class. Xor is the case similar to the pooling arrangements-between railroad carriers (which, however, are illegal, authorities supra), for there the evil of monopoly is checked by the power of the State to regulate prices (Munn v. Illinois, 94 U. S. 113). Finally, this sugar combination-finds no justification or support in the right accorded by law (Penal Code, § 1701) to associations of labor for the enhancement of wages. It is no answer to this criticism of the sugar “ combine ” to say, that a man may do what Em-pleases with his own, that the stock in the several companies is the property of the shareholders, and that they may dispose of it at their pleasure (Authorities, supra). Obviously the scheme of combination constituted by this-deed creates a monopoly in the strictest and most absolute-sense, i. e., a single seller. It concentrates the power of production and supply in a single body, actuated by a single and the same interest; it excludes the possibility of competition, and it tends inevitably to the enhancement of price. Thus-the combination is illegal and criminal, and since a corporation has no authority to do acts which by the public law are indictable" (State v. Krebs, 64 N. C. 604); since acts ultra vires, i. e., abuse of corporate powers (Code Civ. Pro. § 1798, subd. 2), and “ a violation of any provision of law” (Id.), are express statutory grounds of forfeiture, it results that judgment must go against defendant—-if, hr fact, it be a party to the combination.

*171XI. The contention of defendant is, that it is not a party to the agreement or combination, because not made such by any formal regular corporate action; that it could be made a party to the, agreement or combination only by the formal action of its board of trustees, who alone are charged with the conduct of its affairs, and who alone could bind it by an obligatory engagement. But the controlling question of fact is not whether defendant was a party to-the agreement, but whether it is the combination ? It is not a true proposition of law, that the board of trustees is the only or the predominant power in the corporation. True, the.“ concerns” of defendant company are “managed ” by its board of trustees (Act 1848, § 3) ; but the trustees are-elected by the stockholders ” (Id.),—who, therefore, constitute the ultimate and supreme power in the corporation. Nor is it a true proposition of law, that the only misconduct, for which a corporation is liable, when challenged for misconduct by the people, is the misconduct of the officers-through whom, in the legal sense, it acts. In fact the corporators are the corporation / and the notion of a corporate entity, distinct and apart from the natural persons composing the corporation—of a substance separate from its constituents—is a pure fiction, as much so as the finding in an action of trover, on the demise and ouster in the action of ejectment—a fiction invented by the subtle intellect of Ooke, “ for the purpose of perpetual succession " (Marshall, C. J., in Dartmouth College Case, 4 Wheat. 636), but since-exploded and discarded by all scientific writers on the law of corporations (Louisville v. Letson, 2 How. [ U. S.] 497, 552; Steamship v. Tugman, 106 U. S.118; Field on Corp. § 449 ; Boone on Corp § 199 ; 2 Kyd on Corp. 475 ; Ayliffe, Civ. Law, 196 ; 1 Morawetz on Corp. § 474; Bronson, J.,. in People v. Assessors. 1 Hill, 620; 1 Mora, on Corp. § 227; 1 Mora. § 1 ; 2 Id. § 852; Taylor on Corp. § 50 1 Black Com. 484, marginal; 2 Ryd, 477; 2 Id. 478; People v. Kingston, etc., 23 Wend. 205; Webster v. Turner, 12 Hun, *172264; Davis, J., in Binghampton Bridge Case, 3 Wallace, 51, 73).

XII. Defendant is a party to the Sugar Refineries Company deed. Beyond all controversy, the North River ‘Company, or its stockholders, have acted upon the provisions of the deed, have received and enjoyed the benefits of it; and so are parties to it, if not upon the original execution of Moller, then as effectually by subsequent adoption •arid ratification (Sheldon Company v. Eickemeyer Co., 90 N. Y. 607).

XIII. At all events, defendant company is a party to "the combination created and constituted by the Sugar Refineries Company deed.

•XIV. The case then is this: The persons who procured the charter of defendant company were endowed by the ■State with the corporate franchise and the faculties of a body politic, in consideration of the benefit to the public from an increased production of refined sugar, and the consequent greater supply and less price to the community; but so far from appearing in the market as an independent producer, and a competitor in the supply of the commodity, ■and a factor in the reduction of its price, defendant company, by the agency of its constituent members, is introduced into a combination of sugar refineries, of which the apparent and inevitable operation is to limit production, diminish supply, and enhance prices. Indisputably, here is a violation of the trust and a breach of the condition upon which the corporate franchise was conceded to defendant. Indisputably, defendant’s corporate faculties, instead of ■conducing to the benefit of the public, are perverted to its •detriment, and, consequently, it has incurred a forfeiture of its franchises. ■

If a monopoly combination among natural persons be contrary to law, much more is it so between corporations; because ultra vires, and because repugnant to the aim of 'Corporate institution, “ the true ground and original of cor*173porations being the increase and advancement of trade and merchandise ” (Sir Robert Atkin’s Case, 3 Modern, 12).

XV. The combination between the several corporations, resulting from the transfer of their stock to the board, “subject to the purposes set forth in this deed,” is in effect, an amalgamation or consolidation of those corporations, or, at all events, a co-partnership between them. But “ corporations cannot consolidate their funds, or form a partner-, ship, unless authorized by express grant or necessary implication ’’ (N. Y. and Sharon Can Co., etc. v. Fulton Bank, 7 Wend. 412; A. and A. on Corp. § 272; Taylor on Corp. § 305, 419, 420 ; Greens Brice, 416; Mallory v. Oil Works, 2 Pickle [Tenn.], 598 ; 1 Morawetz on Corp. § 376 ; Authorities, supra.)

XV L Defendant corporation has forfeited its charter by the transfer of its control to “ The Sugar Refineries Company ” (Section 3, Act 1848 ; Central R. R. Co. v. Collins,. 40 Ga. 583 ; Chicago, etc. v. Gas Co., 2 Am. State Reports, 124; Bradford, etc. R. R. Co. v. N. Y., etc. R. R. Co., 16 N. Y. State Rep. 208 ; Safer v. R. R. Co., 19 Abb. N. C. 454 ; Vanderbilt v. Bennett, Id. 460, n. ; Thomas v. R. R. Co., 101 U. S. 83).

• XVII. By the transfer of defendant’s stock to the Sugar Refineries Company, “ subject to the purposes of this deed,” the law forbidding the suspension of the absolute ownership of personal ‘property, was violated (1 Edmonds' Stat. 727; Hardwicks, Ch., in Duke of Norfolk’s Case, 1 Vern. 163; 4 Kent, 287).

James C. Carter,

for the defendant, urged in substance,, as follows:—I. The omission to file an annual report when this company did not have any debts or laibpities is not a ground for the forfeiture of the corporate franchise.*

*174II. For an omission of minor or accessory duties which are not strictly essential to the due exercise of the corporate power, the proper remedies are mandamus, prohibition, injunction, indictment or action by the party aggrieved (Thompson v. People, 23 Wend. 537; Sedgwick on Stat. and Com. Law, 341, et seq.).

III. Corporations 'have the same right to suspend the operations of their business for a time as have individuals ; for if corporations were under an obligation to carry on their business, whether it is profitable or not, and in the face of losses, they are under disadvantages which make it impossible for them to carry on business at all.

IV. Even if the agreement into which the stockholder’s •entered is illegal, the charge that the corporation has become a party to it, is unsupported by evidence. In order to make ■out the charge that the corporate body has usurped franchises not given to it by law and forbidden by law, it must be proven that what was done here purported to be a corporate act. The assent of the stockholders to this agreement did not purport or pretend to be corporate action at all.

V. Even if the corporation had entered into this combination even if it were a combination between these corporate bodies, the consequences of which they were' fully chargeable with, that combination is in no manner illegal, but was an act entirely within the rightful powers of any person, artificial or natural, capable of making a contract.

VI. An agreement by which a large number of manufacturers combine to consolidate their interests so as to destroy competition among themselves, is not prohibited by law, when the article manufactured—in this case, sugar—is ■one which may be produced indefinitely by the mere application of labor and capital.

VII. There is no agreement here to restrain trade, nor is there any effort to corner any market.

VIII. The burden here is on the plaintiff to show that the agreement in question is against public policy because it represses competition and enhances prices; and unless this *175proposition, of which the burden is upon them, is established to the entire satisfaction of the court, the action cannot be maintained (Richardson v. Mellish, 2 Bing. 252; Hilton v. Eckersley, 6 E. & B. 47; Printing, etc. Co. v. Sampson, Law Rep. 19 Eq. Cas. 462).

IX. The fact that this is an enormous aggregation of •capital between corporate bodies does not make it a subject for condemnation. The common law permits aggregations ■of capital between individuals, and there is no difference in this respect in the case of corporations.

X. This agreement does not tend to stifle competion or to enhance prices to the consumer, for outside of this •organization there are other refiners of sugar, and therefore competition and prices could not be raised by this combination without raising them for the benefit of the other refiners. Nor does this combination have it in its power to limit the production.

XI. Destruction of competition and enhancement oí •prices result only where the commodity dealt in is one incapable of indefinite production by the mere application of labor and capital. These results are only derived in the case of monopolies, which are created by their having the sole power of buying, selling or manufacturing a given commodity.

XII. The effect of this agreement is not to enhance ■prices, but to diminish them, which is the natural result of production upon a large scale and consequent reduction in price caused by the émployment of new facilities, new machinery, better skill and better ability.

XIII. The grounds upon which the doctrine that agreements in restraint of trade are void is placed are two: 1. The injury which is supposed to arise to the public from -one of its citizens withdrawing himself from his calling; because the public is thereby deprived of the benefit of his industry ; and 2. The injury which arises to the individual -himself in thus disabling himself from gaining support for *176himself and family. The decisions bearing out these propositions have little* application here.

XIV. The decisions bearing upon the doctrine that-agreements—such as where certain persons, who, having the-control of some necessary of life, the supply of which is restricted, combine together to limit its production and thus to enhance its price—which are against public policy and-therefore void, are also inapplicable, as such agreements-create or tend to create a monopoly which does not exist here (Arnot v. Pittston, etc. Coal Co., 68 N. Y. 558).

XV. Other illegal agreements, not applicable to this case,, are those which have for their purpose the cornering of a market; and where laborers combine to prevent others from working at a lower rate of wages than that fixed by them.

XVI. A large number of all the decisions which have-been made in reference to contracts supposed to be prejudicial to public policy have little to do with the present question (Salt Company v. Guthrie, 34 Ohio St. 666; Morris Run Coal Co. v. Barclay Coal Co., 68 Penn. St. 186; Craft v. McCononghy, 79 Ill. 346; Hoffman v. Brooks, 11 Weekly Law Bull. 358).

XVII. The assumption that it is necessarily for the interest of the public that prices should be as low as possible,, and that any raising of them from a point however low, is injurious, is manifestly erroneous. It cannot be for the public benefit that prices' of any commodities should, by ruinous competition, be depressed below the point which-yields to the producer the average protit which is derived from the employment of capital generally. On the contrary this is a direct public injury. Any agreement, therefore, which is calculated and only calculated to prevent ruinous competition and to preserve and maintain prices at a point where the. capital employed receives the average rate-of remuneration and no more, must be praiseworthy.

XVIII. It would not, however, be safe to assume that a. body of capitalists united together to maintain prices would stop at the above-mentioned reasonable point, if they really *177had the power to carry them higher. If, however, they did' not have the power to maintain them at a higher point, any purpose to do so, real or supposed (none is proved in the present case),would be quite immaterial, and the agreement would be wholly free from objection. If the reasoning of that argument is well framed, it follows that, while in the case of a commodity which can be monopolized it is possible to raise and maintain prices above the reasonable point above mentioned, it is not possible in the case of other commodities,-of which sugar is one.

The following authorities are referred to. Many of them bear directly on the foregoing propositions, and they seem to fully sustain them : Skrainka v. Scharringhausen, 8 Mo. App. 522; Mogul Steamship Company v. McGregor, L. R. 15 Q. B. 476; Collins v. Locke, L. R. 4 App. Casas, 674 ; Hare v. London and N. W. Co., 2 Johns. & H. 80 ; Shrewsbury R. R. Co. v. London, etc. Railway Co., 7 Railway Cases, 600; Marsh v. Russell, 66 N. Y. 288; Snow v. Wheeler,. 113 Mass. 179 ; Commonwealth v. Hunt, 4 Met. 111 Benedict v. W. U. Tel. Co., 9 Abb. N. C. 214; Master Stevedores’ Assoc, v. Walsh, 2 Daly, 1.

In addition to these authorities the attention of the court is called to a very instructive article by Mr. George Gunton,. in Yol. 3, No. 3,-of the Political Science Quarterly, on the-Economical and Social Aspects of Trusts; also another article in No. 4 of the same Quarterly, on “ The Legality of Trusts,” by Prof. Dwight.

Charles P. Daly, for the defendant.

The corporation has not, in its corporate capacity, become a party to the deed (Havemeyer v. Havemeyer, 11 J. & S. 517: Barnes v. Brown, 80 N. Y. 537; Faulds v. Yates, 57 Ill. 416; Foll’s Appeal, 91 Pa. St. 434). What was done by-the stockholders of these different corporations, under the agreement entered into by them, and the powers they unitedly vested by their agreement in the board of trustees, was lawful. In an early industrial period! *178of England, what was regarded as an injury to the nation, was brought before the courts, and tested in the ■celebrated case of the Monopolies (11th Coke, page 86 B.), in which case it was held that there were three things incident to a monopoly. 1. The raising of the price. 2. The ■deterioration of the commodity. 3. The impoverishment -of the artificers and others. And it was held that any grant •of the crown producing, or tending to produce, this effect, was void, as an injury to the nation (Egerton v. Brownlow, 4 H. L. Cases, 1; Wilmot's Opinions, 377; West Virginia, etc. Co. v. Ohio, etc. Co., 22 W. Va. 600; Horner v. Graves, 7 Bing. 743 ; Bensley v. Bignold, 5 B. & Al. 341; Barber's Criminal Law, 20 ; 2 R. S. 691, § 8). The cases hold that combinations are unlawful; the design and effect of which necessarily is to give the party combining a monopoly more or less, for any length of time, of the manufacture or sale of a commodity or of rates for transportation, or to regulate and control the price of a commodity, or to control the rate for the transportation of persons or merchandise, or to secure .any pecuniary or other advantage in restraint of trade which would be injurious to the community. The unlawful purpose sought to be effected in all of these cases, was either to ¡raise prices, or rates by means of the combination, or to ¡keep them under its control; so that the effect would be to compel the public to pay higher prices, or rates than they would have to pay, but for the combination (Arnot v. Pittston and Elmira Coal Co., 68 N. Y. 564; Clancy v. Onondago Fine Salt Manuf. Co., 62 Barb. 403; Hooker v. Vandewater, 4 Denio, 532; Stanton v. Allen, 5 Id. 434; Morris Run Coal Co. v. Barclay Coal Co., 68 Pa. St. 173 ; Salt Co. v. Guthrie, 35 Ohio, 666 ; India Bagging Assoc. v. Koch, 14 La. Ann. 168; Hoffman v. Brooks, 11 W. L. Bull. 228; Denier, etc. v. A. T. & S. F. R. R. Co., 15 Fed. 650; Hilton v. Eckersley, 6 El. & Bl. 47; Wright v. Crabbs, 78 Ind. 487; Craft v. McConoughy, 79 Ill. 346; Raymond v. Leavitt, 46 Mich. 447). The following cases will serve to ■show what combinations affecting trade and commerce are *179lawful (Marsh v. Russell, 66 N. Y. 288; reversing 2 Lans. 340; Skrainka v. Scharringhausen, 8 Mo. App. 522; Central Shade Rolling Company v. Cushman, 143 Mass. 353). It is now well settled by numerous cases, both in this country and in England, that either masters, or workmen, have a right to combine for their own protection and for the advancement of their own interest; for the promotion of skill in their own trade, or to prevent overcrowding, and for the obtaining of such wages as they agree to demand, or to lower wages to such a rate as they agree to pay; these being combinations to obtain a benefit, which by the law, the parties •combining have a right to (Collins v. Locke, L.R. 4 App. 674, 685 ; Master Stevedores’ Association v. Walsh, 2 Daly, 1; Hilton v. Eckersley, 6 El. & Bl., 47, 62; Greenhood on Public Policy, pp. 648, 650, and the cases there cited). It is lawful for parties to combine to secure a profit to themselves, •as by agreeing not to compete with each other, where it is not in jurious to the public (Smith’s Wealth of Nations, Vol. 1, ch. VII; 1 Mill’s on Political Economy, pp. 588, 589 [8th ed.]; Opdyke on Political Economy, p. 60-74; Bentham’s Works, Vol. 2, p. 227; Shrewsbury, etc. R. R. Co. v. London, etc. R. R. Co., 6 H. L. Cases, 113; s. c., 2 Mac. & G. 324 ; 21 L. J. Q. B. 89 ; 17 A. & E. N. S. Q. B. 652 ; Hare v. London R. R. Co., 2 J. & H. 80 ; Jur. [N. S.], 1145; Wickens v. Evans, 3 Y. & J. 318; Mitchel v. Reynolds, 1 P. Wm. 181; Trans. Co. v. Pipe Co., 22 W. V. 617; People v. Fisher, 14 Wend. 9).

The agreement in this case is not m restraint of trade. The burden of showing that a contract, or agreement, is in restraint of trade or commerce, and therefore void on grounds of public policy, is upon the party who sets up the illegality; that is, upon the plaintiff in this action (Rousillon v. Rousillon, L. R. 14 Ch. Div. 363, 364; Printing, etc. Co. v. Sampson, L. R. 19 Eq. Ca. p. 465 ; Phippen v. Stickney 3 Met. 389). The objection taken that the provision in the agreement is void that no one of the trustees shall, during the time that he is trustee, buy or sell sugar, or be interested *180directly or indirectly, in the purchase or sale of it for speculation or otherwise, without the vote of the majority of the-board, is unfounded. If it is void, then the only result is-that it cannot, by the common law, be enforced. There is-no other consequence or effect attached to it (Hilton v. Eckersley, 6 El. & B. pp. 64, 75). But the provision is-not void '(Mitchel v. Reynolds, 1. P. Wm. 190 ; Alger v. Statcher, 19 Pick. 52; 2 Parsons on Contracts, 750 [6th ed.] ; Oregon Steam Nav. Co. v. Winsor, 20 Wall. 67; Wright v. Ryder, 36 Cal. 357; Diamond Match Co. v. Rocher, 35 Hun, 421; Beal v. Chase, 31 Mich. 490 Rousillon v. Rousillon, L. R. 14 Ch. Div. 351; Wickens v. Evans, 3 Y. & J. 318). What is relied upon, as an unlawful combination, is not what was done by the corporation acting in its corporate capacity, but by the- stockholders, and there is a material distinction between them and the corporation, which acts by a board of directors, elected by the-stockholders, which board and its successors, have the whole-management of the ordinary business of the corporation (Goodwin v. Hardy, 57 Me. 143; Hyatt v. Allen, 56 N. Y. 553 ; Jones v. Terre Haute R. R. Co., 57 Id. 196; Denton v. Livingston, 9 Johnson, 96; Kean v. Johnson, 9 N.J. Eq. 401-407; Green’s Brice Ultra Vires, 203, 633).

The fact that this corporation omitted to file the certificate required by the act of 1848 constitutes no ground for-the forfeiture of its charter,' as the omission was not intentionally or wrongfully -done, but arose from a mistake as to-the law. The forfeiture of the charter of a corporation is-a very grave procedure, in which courts act with extreme-caution and with great deliberation (State v. Farmer’s College, 32 Ohio St. 487; State v. People’s Mut. Ben. Asso., 42 Ohio St. 584 ; State v. Commercial Bank, 10 Ohio, 535 ; Slee v. Bloom, 5 John. Ch. 379 ; Terrett v. Taylor, 9 Cranch, 51; Dartmouth College Case, 4 Wheat. 698 ; 2 Kent’s Com. 312; Importing and Exporting Co. v. Locke, 50 Ala. 335 ; N. Y. Code, § 1797). There must be something wrong arising from willful abuse or gross neglect *181something more than accidental negligence, or excess of power, or mistake in the exercise of power; a plain misuser or -departure from the chartered powers, or the assuming of privileges which have not been conferred (State v. Farmers’ College, 32 Ohio St. 487; State v. Merchants’, etc. Co., 8 Hump. [Tenn.], 251 ; State v. Pawtuxet Turnp. Co., 8 R. I. 182 ; Bank Commissioners v. Bank of Buffalo, 6 Paige, 497; State v. Columbia & H. T. P. Co., 2 Sneed [Tenn.] 254; People v. Kingston, 23 Wend. 193; People v. Utica Ins. Co., 15 Johnson, 358 ; State v. Société Républicaine, 9 Mo. App. 120 ; Commonwealth v. Pittsburgh, etc. R. R. Co., 58 Pa. St. 45 ; Stuart v. Father Mathew’s Society, 41 Mich. 74; People v. Williamsburgh N. & B. Co., 47 N. Y. 593 ; State v. People’s Mut. etc., 42 Ohio St. 579 ; State v. Bailey, 16 Ind. 46 ; Attorney-General v. Bank of Niagara, Hopkins Ch. 354 ; People v. Bank of Niagara, 6 Cow. 196).

The omission to do business since January last, is no ground for the forfeiture of the charter. The directors of the corporation is the body to judge whether, under the circumstances, the business could be carried on profitably after that, or not, and if it could, it may reasonably be presumed that it would have been, as it is to the interest of the owners that profits should be made (Slee v. Bloom, 19 John. 477 ; Briggs v. Penniman, 8 Cow. 391 ; Brinckerhoff v. Brown, 7 John. C. 217 ; Bradt v. Benedict, 17 N. Y. 93).

The etymological sense is not the legal meaning of the word •“ monopoly ”—the one being a sole seller, the other “ any •combination between merchants to enhance the price of merchandise.” By all authorities, any combination, of which the tendency is to prevent competition and enhance price, is regarded as a monopoly, in a legal sense, and so unlawful ■(1 Mill's Principles of Political Economy, 552 [D. Appleton & Co. 1864]). This combination is a strict monopoly; for the evidence shows that it controls absolutely and com-. *182pletely the supply of sugar in the State of Hew York, and such control in a single State is held by the courts of that State to be a monopoly (Lawrence v. Kidder, 10 Barb. 642; Dunlop v. Gregory, 10 N. Y. 244 ; West Virginia, etc. v. Company, 46 Am. Rep. 527). The law imposes no obligation on the plaintiff to give evidence of the actual effect of the combination in enhancing prices. The agreement constituting the combination is for the construction of the court; and if the tendency of that be to prevent competition and enhance prices, the court will pronounce the combination illegal. Any combination to do an act injurious to trade or commerce is a criminal conspiracy (Penal Code, § 168, subd. 61), and to prevent or restrict competition is injurious to trade and commerce (Hooker v. Vandewater, 4 Denio, 353; People v. Fisher, 14 Wend. 19, and authorities-in opening argument). An otherwise lawful combination-becomes a crime if its intent be to form a monopoly (Parker, Ch. Hence, it is an unwarrantable hypothesis to assume, that the right of incorporation for legitimate business, involves the-right to incorporate for an unlawful purpose. Upon analysis of the deed constituting the combination, it is impossible to resist the conclusion that its sole object, as its obvious-effect-, is, by control of supply and prevention of competition,, to give the board, as representative of the confederate refineries, control of the price of sugar; and the fact of such control, so secured, in the law, stamps the combination as-illegal—as, indeed, a criminal conspiracy (Arnot v. Pittston, etc. Company, 68 N. Y. 558).

The questions to be decided in this case-are, whether the acts complained of are corporate acts; and if so, whether such corporate acts are grounds of forfeiture within section 1798 of the Code of Civil Procedure.* - The People rest their case primarily upon the second and fifth. *183subdivisions of this section, claiming under the second subdivision that the defendant has “ become liable to be-dissolved by the abuse of its powers,” and under the fifth that it has exercised privileges or franchises not conferred upon it by law.

The act compiained of in this connection, is the defendant’s participation.in a combination between the owners of certain sugar refineries. The combination comprises all the sugar refineries in this State, and with a few exceptions in> the United States. This vast combination is denounced by the people as a public menace, as preventive of competition, and as tending to control prices and ci’eate a monopoly. It is defended by the corporation as the mere individual act of its stockholders, in no wise binding upon it, and at all events as a harmless association constituting nothing more serious than an unusually large partnership; in other words, a lawful blending of individual interests in a joint arrangement for mutual protection and benefit.

The first question then to be considered is, whether the corporation, as such, has entered into this combination ; for if it has not, clearly it cannot be deprived of its franchises because of independent and several acts, however illegal, of its stockholders. To a proper appreciation and solution of this question, the precise facts must be gleaned, and the-foundation of the transaction minutely analyzed. Such analysis will also and necessarily throw a clear light upon, the purposes of the project, and thus aid in the solution of the second question—namely, whether the combination is= the innocent association claimed by the defendant, or the-unlawful one charged by the plaintiff.

Let us then consider the foundation of the combination. It rests upon a written agreement which has been styled the “ trust deed.” At the time this deed was prepared, sugar refineries in this State and country were variously-organized. Some were simple partnerships; others corporations. Evidently the first step contemplated by the author-of the scheme, was harmony in the fundamental business^ *184-basis of each refinery. The combination never could have >been successfully created upon the basis of a special or quasi-partnership arrangement between partnerships and corporations. It was necessary, therefore, either to turn the corporations into partnerships, or the partnerships into •corporations. It did not require the .astuté mind that .prepared this most original instrument to perceive that an aggregation of partnerships, with the dangers resulting •from death and the exercise of individual power, would never effect safe and permanent cohesion. Accordingly we .find, as one-of the first provisions in the deed and as the basis of the so-called trust structure, a condition in sub•stance that the partnerships shall all be turned into corporations. This in fact was done; and thus several of these corporations were organized for the express purpose of creating the very shares of capital stock through which the combination was to be formed. Partners took on corporate .garb, became shareholders, and as such fitted themselves to enter the combination within the terms of the deed. Having thus provided for uniformity of corporate existence, the deed specifies what is to be done by each of the corporations—formed or to be formed. The corporations already formed agree for themselves, and the partnerships agree for those corporations which they are to form, that all the shares of the capital stock of all the corporations shall be transferred to a board consisting of eleven persons (named in the deed) as trustees, to be held by them and their suecessors, strictly as joint tenants, subject to the purposes set forth in 'the deed. These purposes are declared to be :

1. To promote economy of administration and to reduce the cost of refining, thus enabling the price of sugar to be kept as low as is consistent with reasonable profit.
2. To give to each refinery the benefit of all appliances ■and processes known or used by the others, and useful to improve the quality and diminish the cost of refined sugar.
3. To furnish protection against unlawful combinations •of labor.
*1854. To protect against inducements to,lower the standard ■of refined sugars.
5. Generally to promote the interests of the parties hereto in all lawful and suitable ways.

The board is authorized to make by-laws, to appoint from its members a president, vice-president, treasurer, and committees ; and to prescribe their duties and powers. The board is thus clothed with a power co-extensive with the specified objects of the agreement, as applied to the business' •of each refinery ; and it may confer the executive working •of that power upon a president or vice-president. Having thus formed the trust, named the trustees, and specified their powers, the deed proceeds to indicate the persons for whom the trust is created and the duties of the trustees with regard to such persons. The cestuis gue trustent are, of course, the entire body of stockholders of the aggregated corpor.ations. It will be observed that these stockholders do not sell a single share of their stock. Tet they transfer the entire block to eleven gentlemen, who are thereafter to stand in their shoes. They would, naturally, look for some .acknowledgment from their trustees of the receipt of their shares and of the obligations which the trust imposes. The deed proceeds to furnish this in the shape of what are termed trust certificates. These certificates are not to exceed $50,000,000, and are to be divided in 500,000 shares, each of $100. They are to be divided by the eleven trustees among the several refineries, in due proportion to the value of their respective plants; and the refineries are then to subdivide the blocks of certificates, so assigned to them, among the •icestuis gue trustent in proportion to the stock of the corporation which each cestui gue trust held prior to the transfer to the trust board. The form of the trust certificate is preeisvly like the certificate of stock in a corporation. The •eleven trustees are not named, but are styled “ The Sugar Refineries’ Company,” and each certificate specifies that it is issued under and subject to the provisions of the trust deed. The usual blank form of assignment and power of attorney *186is endorsed upon this certificate, with an addendum to the-effect that the assignee, by accepting the transfer, assents to the terms of the trust deed.

To avoid confusion of thought, and to distinguish clearly between the eleven trustees constituted by the deed and the-trustees of the various corporations, we will hereafter speak of the former as the “trust board” or “ the trustees,” and of the latter as “the directors.”

Upon the acceptance of the trust certificate the original corporate shareholder ceases to hold any further relations with his particular corporation, and thenceforward he is treated as a shareholder in the trust board. He can no longer receive a dividend from his particular corporation, nor indeed can the latter ever again declare a dividend. Each corporation is thereafter bound by a special provision in the' deed to pay over the profits arising from its business to the trust board. Ho discretion on that head is left in the directors of the various corporations. They cannot use any part of such profits for betterments or improved machinery, or increased capacity—certainly not without the consent of the trust board—but must pay over all the profits directly to the trustees. Xor can even the latter declare a dividend upon the trust certificates allotted to the shareholders of any one corporation payable out of the profits received from such corporation. On the contrary, their duty is to blend all the profits received from all the corporations into one grand mass, and from that aggregation of profits ■ declare such dividends as they in their judgment deem appropriate, to be proportionately distributed to the holder of each trust certificate.

To emphasize these positions it may be well to quote the precise language of the deed.

“ profits :

“ The profits arising from the business of each corporation shall be paid over by it to the board hereby created, and the aggregate of said profits, or such amounts as may be designated for dividends, shall be proportionately distributed *187by said board, at such time as it may determine, to the-holders of the certificates issued bv said board for capital stock, as hereinbefore provided.”

Thus it will be seen that these dividends are not to be declared or distributed upon the aggregate capital stock of' the corporations, which is to be turned over to and held by the trustees, but upon what might not inaptly, in view of these peculiar facts, be termed the trust board’s capital-stock, namely, the trust certificates.

Thus we have a series of corporations existing and transacting business under the forms of law, without real membership or genuinely qualified direction—mere abstract figments of statutory creation—without life in the concrete or-underlying association. Every share of stock has been practically surrendered and vital membership resigned. With the transfer to the eleven trustees, the shareholders cease to occupy the position of cestuis que trustent with regard to the directors of the various corporations. In lieu thereof, they accept substituted membership in an unincorporated board, and an entirely new, independent and exclusive trust relation with the trustees of that board. Nor are the trustees, as transferees of the capital stock of the various corporations, in any just sense genuine members thereof. They have no beneficial interest therein. Dividends are not declarable thereon, and, if they were, would not be payable to them in their own right, nor as-.trustees for the shareholders in the particular corporation which had earned the dividend. Nor could the owners of' the trust certificates, “ proportionately distributed ” to such corporate shareholders, follow such dividend and require-the trustees to account to them therefor. Whatever dividends are to be declared by the trustees must be so declared and paid from the aggregate fund ; and whatever rights the holders of such trust certificates may have as against the-trustees, can only be enforced by the totality of certificate holders or a representative of that body. Again, the relation existing under the deed between the trustees of the? *188trust and the directors of the corporations is not, as we have seen, the usual relation of shareholders and directors, but a ■strict contract relation. Ordinarily, the directors of a corporation may use their honest judgment with regard to •dividends, and also as to the judicious application of profits. Here, however, the deed treats the directors of the various corporations as mere agents of the trust board, and in ■unqualified terms requires them to “pay over the profits.” ’The effect of this would be the same, even if individual members of the trust board were also shareholders in the ■corporations. As such individuals, they would transfer their shares to the board and accept from the board their •due proportion of the trust certificates. The board, as a board, takes all the shares of all the corporations, and the ■corporate shareholders, whether members of the trust board ■or not, by transferring their shares to these trustees, and ■accepting from the latter trust certificates, in effect, abandon their corporations, relinquish their powers as shareholders, resign their functions as corporators, and look solely to the trust board for future guidance, control and profit.

It is the first time in the history of corporations that we have heard of a double trust in their management and control—one set of trustees elected formally to manage the ■corporate affairs, and a second set created to manage the first—the shareholders in seventeen corporations leaving tlieir functions with regard to their regular directors to be .thought out and performed by them by what amounts to a board of guardians.

Let us now look at the situation of the directors of the various corporations as pointed out in the deed. The statute requires that each director shall be a stockholder. 'Consequently, each director must own at least one share. But the deed requires the transfer to the trustees of every ■share in every corporation. How, these trustees certainly ■cannot, under the terms of their trust, sell or pledge a sin\gle share of the stock thus held by them. This stock in ■their hands is substantially dead. It evidences no individ*189ual right. It measures no proportionate interest. In fact,, it serves in the future no purpose whatever, except to furnish the trust board with formal voting power to control the direction of all the corporations. It would seem to be impossible, therefore, to qualify the boards of directors in the various corporations. The draughtsman, however, attempted to provide for this difficulty by the following provision :

“ The said board may transfer, from time to time, to-such persons as it may be desired to constitute trustees, or directors, or other officers of corporations, so many of the-shares as may be necessary for that purpose, to be held by them subject to the provisions of this instrument. Such transfers may be executed by the president and treasurer of the board in behalf of, and as attorneys for, the board for-that purpose, and to be retransferred when so requested by the board.”

Here there is no pretense of a sale. The “ necessary shares may be transferred to such persons as the board may desire to constitute directors, to be held by such directors “subject to the provisions” of the trust deed and to be “retransferred” when so requested by the board. This clearly bears out my previous observation that these corporations exist as creatures of the law, and are conducting business under its authority without a single genuinely qualified director; in fact, without directors at all in the ordinary and legal sense. Every director in every one of the corporations is necessarily the mere creature and agent of the trust board. The share of stock put in his name is not his property, nor can a dividend ever be declared upon it to him or to any one else. For that very share a trust certificate has, in fact, already been issued to him or' to some one else. Plainly, then, the holding of this lifeless share of stock by the director, without beneficial interest and at the will of the board—“ to be retransferred when requested is not a compliance with the statutory require-*190merits that the directors shall “ respectively be stockholders in such company.”

There is further evidence upon the face of the deed, of the difficulties which surrounded the execution of the contemplated project. Each refinery might have had debts, and all probably had assets outside of its plant. It would have been impracticable to issue trust certificates in proportion to the capital stock of each company, for one company might be capitalized for much more than its real value, while another might be capitalized for less, and still another for its precise value. It was necessary, therefore, to distribute the trust certificates in proportion to the real value of each property. But, here again, there, was a difficulty growing •out of the complexity of mortgages upon the realty, float- ' ing debt and the possession of raw material and other personal property. It was clear that the interests in the trust board, which were to be substituted for the corporate shares, must be proportioned upon the realty, fixtures and machinery ■of each company (freed from debt), exclusive of the transmutable stock and other personal property ; in other words, upon the naked plant. Accordingly, provision is made in the deed that each refinery and the corporation to which it belongs shall be freed from liability and indebtedness by the parties interested in it; or such parties, if the board ¡shall approve, may provide in cash for such indebtedness or liability, leaving the same to stand at the pleasure of the board. So much for the debts. Then as to the assets other than the plant, provision is made for their appraisal by five •of the eleven trustees, and the values thus fixed are to be paid in cash by the trust board to the treasurer of each corporation. *191This covers, in a general way, the methods adopted by the parties to produce cohesion as between themselves. But they did not stop there. Provision is made for the .gathering in of every other existing refinery (“ in every instance to be incorporated ”), and, in fact, four others have joined the combination since the deed was signed by the ■original partnerships and corporations; and the evidence shows that in the entire country but five sugar refineries of the character in question remain outside of the combination. That, at once, necessarily disqualified every director in every corporation,, unless indeed a single share was reserved or transferred to-each of such directors under the authority of the- clause of the trust deed to which we have referred. It that was done,, and as these directors have continued to perform their ordinary functions, we must assume that it was done, then the-deed again became an executed contract, and the directors held their offices or continued to perform their duties by the-force of its provisions. It also appears in connection with this particular defendant, that Mr. Searles, immediately after the purchase of the stock, became its president and treasurer, put in new directors, and, at once, for reasons satisfactory to himself, discontinued the business.
